annotation.summary: An introductory section explaining the fundamentals of Starfinder, covering character creation, leveling, and a brief overview of the game's setting and deities.
This section introduces ancestries and heritages from the Pact Worlds, detailing their ancestry feats. It also includes backgrounds and a discussion of languages influenced by ancestry choice.

The chapter outlines rules for eight character classes, detailing how to play, build, and advance each one, including sample builds and class feats. It also introduces archetypes, which let characters gain abilities from other classes or concepts as they level up.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must be eligible to select a class or archetype as defined in the chapter.

annotation.summary: This section explains how skill use is determined by a character’s proficiency rank, which is influenced by their ancestry, background, class, and personal choices that represent their training and personality.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must have defined ancestry, background, and class to determine initial skill proficiencies.

annotation.summary: As characters level up, they gain feats that reflect their increasing capabilities. This section introduces general feats and the subset known as skill feats.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must gain levels to access additional feats

annotation.summary: The chapter outlines the rules for casting and counteracting spells, provides spell lists organized by tradition and rank, details individual spell descriptions, includes focus spells tied to specific classes, and concludes with rules for performing rituals that any character can attempt.
annotation.action_economy: Covers various spellcasting actions including casting, counteracting, and performing rituals, each with their own time and requirements.
annotation.prerequisites: Access to spellcasting abilities or class features that grant spells or focus spells; any character may attempt rituals.

annotation.summary: The paragraph explains that in Starfinder, certain game terms like statistics, skills, feats, and actions are capitalized to indicate they are specific mechanical elements within the rules.
The paragraph explains that an activity requires all of its listed actions to produce its effects, with spellcasting given as a common example since most spells need multiple actions to complete.
annotation.action_economy: An activity consumes all of its required actions before its effects occur.
annotation.prerequisites: Must have enough available actions to perform the entire activity.

annotation.summary: The paragraph explains the symbols representing activities that require two or three actions, and mentions that some special activities, like certain spells, use a free action or a reaction instead.

action_economy.two_actions: Activities marked with [two-actions] require two actions to perform.
action_economy.three_actions: Activities marked with [three-actions] require three actions to perform.
action_economy.free_action: Some special activities, such as instant spells, use a free action.
action_economy.reaction: Certain special activities can be performed as reactions.

annotation.prerequisites: None specified.

annotation.summary: The paragraph explains that while all characters share access to basic actions, individual characters can gain unique abilities through special rules, primarily granted by feats obtained during character creation or level advancement.
annotation.action_economy: Basic actions are universally available; additional actions or abilities depend on feats or special rules.
annotation.prerequisites: Feats or special rules acquired through character creation choices or leveling up.

annotation.summary: All game mechanics are presented as stat blocks that summarize the necessary rules for monsters, characters, items, or other elements. Some sections include explanations of how to read these stat blocks, such as the ancestry section in Chapter 2.
The paragraph explains that spells, tech items, and magic items share a similar stat block structure but include unique elements, such as listing possible magical traditions for spells.
Describes the requirements a character must meet to select a rule element, such as minimum attributes, feats, proficiency ranks, or level prerequisites for feats.
annotation.prerequisites: Minimum attributes, feats, proficiency ranks, and level prerequisites for feats.

annotation.summary: The 'Special' section of a rule describes any unique qualities or exceptions, often clarifying effects when a feat can be taken multiple times.
annotation.prerequisites: None

annotation.summary: The section explains that pages 27–28 contain charts showing ancestries and classes with their respective attribute boosts and flaws, helping players optimize their starting attributes. It also references page 23 for more details on attribute modifiers.
annotation.prerequisites: Access to pages 23 and 27–28 of the rulebook for full details on attribute modifiers and ancestry information.

annotation.summary: A character’s background influences their attribute modifiers, offering more flexibility in attribute boosts compared to class-based ones. Detailed background descriptions are found on pages 92–96.

The paragraph advises players to reflect on their characters' motivations and backgrounds, review available ancestries, backgrounds, and classes to align with their concept, and collaborate with other players to establish character relationships before the game begins.
annotation.prerequisites: None; intended for players preparing characters before starting a campaign.

annotation.summary: The paragraph explains that players can build character concepts in Starfinder by choosing from ancestries, backgrounds, and classes. Each ancestry includes heritages that further refine a character, and some heritages, called versatile heritages, can be applied to any ancestry. References are made to other sections of the rulebook for more details.
annotation.prerequisites: None; players simply choose from available ancestries, backgrounds, and classes when creating a character.

annotation.summary: This passage introduces the concept of backgrounds, which describe a character’s upbringing, hobbies, or profession, and notes that detailed information can be found in Chapter 2 starting on page 92.
Intelligence represents a character’s capacity for learning, reasoning, and analysis. Higher Intelligence grants additional trained skills and the ability to learn more languages.
Charisma represents a character's charm, confidence, and ability to influence others through social interaction.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; this is a descriptive attribute, not an action.
annotation.prerequisites: None; Charisma is a core ability score assigned during character creation.

annotation.summary: The paragraph instructs players to record their ancestry-based abilities and feats in the correct sections of their character sheet, including senses, innate spells, and ancestry feats.
annotation.prerequisites: character must have a chosen ancestry and ancestry feat

annotation.summary: Backgrounds describe a character’s life before adventuring and grant attribute boosts, skill training, a Lore skill, and a skill feat.
annotation.prerequisites: Character creation stage; no prior requirements.

annotation.summary: Describes how to determine a character's starting proficiency ranks, including choosing trained skills and handling overlaps between class and background proficiencies.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must be at the stage of selecting initial proficiencies during character creation.

annotation.summary: The paragraph explains that players should consult their class advancement table to determine which features they gain at 1st level. It notes that ancestry, background, and attribute boosts are already chosen but shown for reference, and that some class features may require further choices like selecting spells.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must have chosen ancestry, background, and attribute boosts before applying class features.

annotation.summary: The paragraph instructs players on how to fill out their character sheet, including recording total Hit Points, marking proficiency levels for perception, saving throws, and skills, and noting armor, weapon, and class abilities in their respective sections. It emphasizes marking trained or expert proficiencies and defers finalizing statistics until a later step.
annotation.prerequisites: Character creation process prior to Step 9; class and skill selections determined.

annotation.summary: This section explains that a character's class defines their proficiency with certain weapons and armor, which in turn affect their damage output and Armor Class. Detailed calculations are provided in a later step.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must have a defined class to determine weapon and armor training.

annotation.summary: The paragraph advises players to acquire basic adventuring gear such as tools, lighting, and medical supplies, while noting that advanced items like augmentations, armor or weapon upgrades, and magic items are expensive early on. It directs readers to Chapter 6 for detailed equipment lists and prices.
annotation.prerequisites: none

annotation.summary: Players can choose to ignore the default attribute boosts and flaws of their ancestry and instead select two free attribute boosts during character creation, allowing for more customization.
annotation.prerequisites: Character creation phase; must be selecting ancestry attributes.

annotation.summary: This paragraph explains that players should record their weapons and other equipment on the character sheet, then calculate attack bonuses for melee and ranged Strikes in Step 9 and Armor Class when wearing armor in Step 10.
annotation.prerequisites: Completion of earlier character creation steps before Step 9 and Step 10.

annotation.summary: Explains how to calculate each type of saving throw by combining the relevant proficiency bonus, the associated ability modifier, and any constant bonuses or penalties from abilities, feats, or items.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must have established proficiency bonuses and ability modifiers for Constitution, Dexterity, and Wisdom.

annotation.summary: Explains how to calculate a character's total skill modifier by combining the relevant attribute modifier, proficiency bonus (if trained), and any other bonuses or penalties.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must have defined attribute modifiers and proficiency status for each skill.

annotation.summary: Instructions for filling out character sheet sections related to Perception, saving throws, attacks, and skills by combining proficiency bonuses and attribute modifiers to calculate total modifiers and record them in the appropriate boxes.
annotation.prerequisites: character sheet with proficiency bonus and attribute modifiers determined

annotation.summary: Explains how to include constant and situational modifiers in a character's total modifiers, adding permanent ones directly and noting conditional ones separately.
annotation.prerequisites: character has feats or abilities that grant modifiers

annotation.summary: This paragraph explains that while many characters can learn minor magical abilities, the mystic and witchwarper classes gain full spellcasting capabilities. Players whose classes grant spells should review how their spells work during character creation, record their magical tradition, proficiency ranks, and spell repertoire on the character sheet. Detailed spellcasting rules are found in Chapter 7.
annotation.action_economy: Not specified; general reference to spellcasting mechanics.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must belong to a class that grants spellcasting, such as mystic or witchwarper.

annotation.summary: Characters start each session with 1 Hero Point and can earn more through heroic actions or enthusiastic play. Hero Points can be spent for benefits like avoiding death or rerolling a d20.
annotation.action_economy: Spending a Hero Point is typically a free action or reaction depending on the benefit used.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must possess at least 1 Hero Point to use its benefits.

annotation.summary: Jessica selects the Recluse background for her ex-Starfinder character, assigning Constitution and Strength as attribute boosts, records 'Dubious Knowledge' as the background skill feat, and chooses 'Starfinder Lore' and 'Survival' as trained skills.
annotation.prerequisites: Character creation step; access to the Recluse background.

annotation.summary: Jessica allocates four attribute boosts to finalize her starting modifiers, prioritizing Strength for her class and distributing the rest to Dexterity, Constitution, and Intelligence to reflect her combat and skill background.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must be at the stage of assigning starting attribute boosts during character creation.

annotation.summary: Jessica finalizes her character’s skill training and hit points. As a solarian, she automatically trains in Athletics and selects four additional skills—Computers, Acrobatics, Occultism, Survival, and Thievery—marking them all as trained. She then calculates her total hit points by adding class and ancestry values plus her Constitution modifier, reaching 23 HP.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must be a solarian with shirren ancestry; skill selection depends on Intelligence modifier.

annotation.summary: Jessica records her solar manifestations for her character, selecting a halberd as her solar weapon with graviton and solar forms, notes its reach trait, adds Solar Shot forms for ranged attacks, lists Nimbus Surge as a reaction, and selects the Stellar Rush feat.

Jessica selects her starting equipment, including medium freebooter armor with a comm unit, a semi-auto pistol with extra ammo, a hacking toolkit, and an infiltrator's toolkit. She records these items on her character sheet, listing the pistol under ranged Strikes and the rest in her inventory, tracking remaining credits.
annotation.action_economy: None; this section describes character setup, not in-game actions.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must be trained in medium armor and have access to starting credits for purchasing equipment.

annotation.summary: The paragraph explains how to record and calculate modifiers for various statistics, including adding proficiency bonuses based on training or expertise levels.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must have determined attribute modifiers and training or expertise levels.

annotation.summary: Ysoki are adaptable and resourceful individuals who use their talents to support their families and communities.

This section explains how to apply new abilities, feats, attribute boosts, skill increases, and spellcasting options gained through leveling up, directing players to the appropriate chapters for each type of advancement.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; this passage describes character progression, not in-game actions.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must have a defined class and ancestry to apply the referenced feats and increases.

annotation.summary: The paragraph instructs players to review their spell list in Chapter 7 to determine if any spells have heightened versions they are now able to cast.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must have access to spells and meet the level or ability requirements for heightened versions.

annotation.summary: Players choose feats according to their class advancement table, referencing specific chapters for ancestry, class, general, and skill feats.
annotation.prerequisites: Access to a class advancement table and relevant chapters for feat selection.

annotation.summary: If your character's class provides spellcasting, include the appropriate spells and spell slots as described in Chapter 7.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must belong to a class that grants spellcasting.

annotation.summary: Recalculate any bonuses granted by feats or abilities that depend on your current character level.
annotation.prerequisites: Character level change or recalculation event

annotation.summary: When an ability score modifier changes, recalculate derived statistics such as maximum Hit Points or trained skills. A higher Constitution modifier increases Hit Points per level, while a higher Intelligence modifier grants an extra trained skill and language. Level-based feat benefits, like those from Toughness, are also updated whenever the character gains a level.
annotation.prerequisites: A change in an ability score modifier or gaining a new level.
